category.name: Design
category.description: Master design principles, user experience, and visual communication techniques.

sub_categories.name: Graphic Design
sub_categories.description: Learn graphic design principles and visual communication techniques.

exercises.title: Design Principles
exercises.description: Learn fundamental graphic design principles and concepts.

tasks.title: Balance in Design
tasks.question:
What is balance in graphic design?

Consider: Visual weight distribution
tasks.hint: Think about how elements are distributed in a design
options: Distribution of visual weight to create stability

tasks.title: Contrast in Design
tasks.question:
What is the purpose of contrast in graphic design?

Consider: Making elements stand out
tasks.hint: Think about creating visual interest and hierarchy
options: Creating visual interest and emphasizing differences

tasks.title: Proximity in Design
tasks.question:
What does proximity refer to in design?

Consider: How close elements are to each other
tasks.hint: Think about grouping related elements together

exercises.title: Typography Fundamentals
exercises.description: Learn fundamental typography principles and techniques.

tasks.title: Typeface vs Font
tasks.question:
What is the difference between a typeface and a font?

Consider: Design vs. digital file
tasks.hint: Think about the design vs. the digital implementation
options: Typeface is the design, font is the digital file
Font is the design, typeface is the digital file

tasks.title: Serif vs Sans Serif
tasks.question:
What is the main difference between serif and sans serif fonts?

Consider: Decorative elements
tasks.hint: Think about the small decorative strokes
options: Serif fonts have decorative strokes, sans serif don't
Sans serif fonts are always bold

tasks.title: Typography Hierarchy
tasks.question:
What is typography hierarchy used for?

Consider: Organizing information
tasks.hint: Think about guiding the reader's eye
options: Making all text the same size
Organizing information to guide the reader's eye
Making text as small as possible
